instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
Good morning all,

I am new to the forum.
I have several <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with the same problem :
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
SMC work, main power rails work

I accumulated these boards because I was running out of time to working them
What do you recommend to check first?
Thanks in advance :)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

ALWAYS check diode mode on all big coils, before apply power to the board.
When you have the board alone on the desk I don't understand why many people don't do that first.
Compare with working board, or your notes taken from other repaurs.
If no short, or low values, then apply power.
Do I consider you already did that, or should I ask you to check now???

You didn't post exact voltage for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> even; very important information.
Do you have original Magsafe 2 charger?

Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, PM_PWRBTN_, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and the 4 PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
Hello my friend, 

Yes, thanks for the tip, now I am checking the coils.

In my case everything is ok

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.48V
Yes, I am using Apple original magsafe

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3,31V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3,39V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 3,42V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3,42V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3,25V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3,41V
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 2,74V

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> 2,59V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> 2,74V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 2,82V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 2,82V

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 2,82V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3,3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5RS3RS0_SYSCLKGEN</SIGNAL> 3,3V
PP1V2_CAM_XTALPCIEVDD 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBTLC</SIGNAL> 0,5V

I replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, the measurements remain the same.

Thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
If present, check for pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals at same time.

Did you try SMC bypass mode?

Tip: use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads, instead of power button.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
Yes <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> there is the fall and go back up right away

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> = 0,052V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 3,32V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> rails have a 3.3V pulsation when I trigger

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
Can you clarify please???
You've posted 0V (means steady???), for first 3 <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> signals, then said all pulsing :eek:...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0V (3.3V pulsation when I trigger)
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0V (3.3V pulsation when I trigger)
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> = 0V (3.3V pulsation when I trigger)
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> = 0,052V (3.3V pulsation when I trigger)
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 3,32V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
Then the controlled Sx power rails should pulse too.
For example, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> enables S3 voltages.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> enables S0 voltages.
Check them all.

"Did you try SMC bypass mode?"
???
"How to" details on the forum...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message: It does not start in SMC bypass...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message: Yes, i have just test and this board work on bypass SMC mode

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
Check first <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> voltage.
Post exact ohm resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Post <SIGNAL>CHGR_A</SIGNAL>/BMON levels.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> = 0V with fast pulse every 2 seconds
pins 27/28 = 21,1 ohm
pins 17/18 = 3,2 ohm
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> 0,029v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> = 0V"
Must be present, even in off state.
Post dioe mode to ground there.
Check the trace for pin 8/<CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.
Also inspect <CAPACITOR>C5021</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C5125</CAPACITOR> for corrosion.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
threads.message:
Thank you very much thanks to you I was able to repair 2 cards indeed the problems were linked to <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and its continuity.

I believed the presence of <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> eliminated the SMC problems ...

Thanks for your help :)
